title: I have 2 UCC-1 filings against me. One was paid on time and the other was debt discharged on a chapter 7 bankruptcy.
question: I have called both and asked them to remove and they state they will not. Both are real estate commission advances.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Debt,Lien,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers:
I would need more information to answer this question. Do the UCC filings relate to a lawsuit and/or judgment on the commission advances? Or is it just for the commission advances only?

Generally, the best way to approach this is to put the request to release it in writing so you create a paper trail. If they persist, then you can contact the California Secretary of State and follow the procedure for contesting the filing. If all else fails, they you may have to pursue a court case to get an order forcing them to release it. I would recommend that you speak to a lawyer before starting any kind of case.

I agree with the other attorneys' excellent answers.

The lien that was paid should be removed as satisfied (if you really did pay the full amount). As for the other lien, as already stated, bankruptcy does not discharge liens. You need to get with your bankruptcy attorney and determine if you have any options to have the lien removed by filing a motion in your bankruptcy.

A UCC-1 filing is done to give notice to the world that a creditor holds a lien on some type of property. The property could be business equipment, a boat in some states, personal items such a TVs, stereos, lawnmowers, etc. Debt is discharged in bankruptcy. Liens are not discharged. Thus, the creditor is within its rights to refuse to file a UCC Termination statement.
